urn:contentItem:60P7-0281-JC5B-G3S4-00000-00S&P 500 ticks up as 'era of easy money' looks set to last2020-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:20ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSDOMESTIC NEWSS&P 500 ticks up as 'era of easy money' looks set to lastSTAN CHOE and DAMIAN J. TROISEAP Business WritersNEW YORK

NEW YORK — The S&P 500 ticked further into record territory on Thursday after the Federal Reserve made a major overhaul to its strategy, one that could keep interest rates low for longer.

The benchmark index rose 0.2%, to another all-time high, but it veered through a jumbled day of trading to get there. Prices for stocks, bonds and gold all made several U-turns after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave a highly anticipated speech. In it, he essentially said the Fed may continue efforts to prop up the economy even if inflation rises above its target level of 2%, as long as it had been weak before then.

The change in the Fed's strategy is a huge deal for markets. The central bank has been the superhero repeatedly rescuing them from crises through the years, by slashing short-term interest rates and buying all kinds of bonds. The momentous announcement was widely expected on Wall Street, if not on Thursday then later this year, but trading was nevertheless erratic following it.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 160.35 points, or 0.6%, to 28,492.27 after fading back from an earlier gain of 302 points. The Nasdaq composite, meanwhile, fell 39.72 points, or 0.3%, to 11,625.34 after paring an earlier loss of 1%.

The benchmark S&P 500 gained 5.82 points to 3,484.55 to set a closing record for the fifth straight day. It's surged nearly 56% since late March after the immense support of the Fed helped halt its earlier free-fall and erase its pandemic losses. Low rates often act like steroids for stocks, allowing their prices to rise faster than corporate profits.

“The era of easy money is here,” said Mike Loewengart, managing director of investment strategy at E-Trade Financial.

Treasury yields fell immediately after Powell began talking, but then started bouncing up and down. The yield of the 10-year Treasury was at 0.74% after stocks stopped trading on Wall Street, up from 0.68% late Wednesday. The 30-year yield climbed to 1.50% from 1.41%.

Shorter-term Treasury yields were more subdued, and the two-year yield held at 0.14%. The widening gap between short- and longer-term yields could be an indication of higher expectations for the economy or inflation among investors.

Gold for delivery in December fell $19.90 to settle at $1,932.60 per ounce. Earlier, it had leaped to $1,968.80 after Powell began talking. Lower Treasury yields can drive demand for gold from investors seeking safety but not interested in the lower interest payments coming from bonds.

Earlier in the morning, a report showed the pace of layoffs sweeping the country remains incredibly high but may be slowing. A little more than 1 million U.S. workers applied for unemployment benefits last week, which was a dip from the slightly more than 1.1 million the prior week.

“It puts a spotlight on the heavy lifting the economy is going to need to get people back in the jobs market,” said Marvin Loh, senior global macro strategist at State Street.

He said investors are still banking on Congress delivering another round of aid for the economy, which could include benefits for unemployed workers. Much of Congress' last round of stimulus has expired, and investors say a renewal is critical, though partisan disagreements have prevented a deal.

“It’s a necessary result that has to come out of Washington sooner rather than later,” Loh said.

In another report, the government also said that the economy looks like it shrank at an annual rate of 31.7% in the spring quarter. That would be the sharpest quarterly drop on record, but it’s not as bad as the Commerce Department’s earlier estimate of 32.9%.

Abbott Laboratories jumped 7.8% for one of the biggest gains in the S&P 500 after federal regulators gave emergency use authorization for its COVID-19 test, which can provide results in 15 minutes and will cost only $5.

Stocks of companies that sorely need people feeling comfortable enough with the pandemic to get back to “normal” life were also strong. Live Nation Entertainment rose 8.8%, Norwegian Cruise Line was up 5.9% and United Airlines rallied 5.8%.

Financial stocks had the biggest gain among the 11 sectors that make up the S&P 500, up 1.7%. A higher 10-year Treasury yield allows for higher rates on mortgages and other loans, which boosts profits for banks. JPMorgan Chase gained 3.3%, and Wells Fargo rose 2.3%.

Counterbalancing those gains were losses for some big tech and internet companies, which gave back some of their slingshot, earlier gains. Apple slipped 1.2%. It's coming off four straight weeks where it rocketed up by 3% to 14.7%.

In European stock markets, the German DAX lost 0.7%, and France's CAC 40 slipped 0.6%. The FTSE 100 in London was down 0.8%.

In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.4%, and South Korea's Kospi lost 1%. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong fell 0.8%, and stocks in Shanghai rose 0.6%.

Benchmark U.S. crude oil fell 35 cents to settle at $43.04 per barrel. Brent crude, the international standard, lost 55 cents to $$45.09 per barrel.

It's coming off four straight weeks where it rocketed up by 3% to 14.7%. In European stock markets, the German DAX lost 0.7%, and France's CAC 40 slipped 0.6%. The FTSE 100 in London was down 0.8%. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.4%, and South Korea's Kospi lost 1%. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong fell 0.8%, and stocks in Shanghai rose 0.6%. Benchmark U.S. crude oil fell 35 cents to settle at $43.04 per barrel. Brent crude, the international standard, lost 55 cents to $$45.09 per barrel. Companies Mentioned in This Article Compare These Stocks[1] Add These Stocks to My Watchlist[2] 10 Buy and Hold Stocks to Add to Your Portfolio[3]'Set it and forget it' are words many investors don't want to hear. Even the most venerable brokerage houses are encouraging their clients to actively trade so they can beat the market. Buy and hold is a relic, they say. It doesn't reflect the reality of today. In other words, 'this time it's different'. As the ongoing volatility in the market shows you, it's not different. It's not even close to being different. The simple fact is that many active traders lose money by being too aggressive and too active for their own good. And while it's true that the market won't always be this choppy, and certain stocks may be a great buy in months to come, right now investors are looking for safe harbors. One of the safest ways to invest is to find stocks that you can feel comfortable holding on to even in the worst of times. Frequently that can be because the stocks offer an attractive dividend. But sometimes, it's also because they are in a market that is always in demand. But that doesn't mean you have to limit yourself to defensive stocks. You can find some quality buy-and-hold stocks that offer some attractive growth prospects. View the "10 Buy and Hold Stocks to Add to Your Portfolio"[4]. urn:contentItem:60PD-5NN1-F07F-83W8-00000-00S&P 500 Ticks Up as ‘era of Easy Money' Looks Set to Last2020-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:20ZLexisNexisNEWSS&P 500 Ticks Up as ‘era of Easy Money' Looks Set to Last

The S&P 500 ticked further into record territory on Thursday after the Federal Reserve made a major overhaul to its strategy, one that could keep interest rates low for longer. The benchmark index rose 0.2%, to another all-time high, but it veered through ... The S&P 500 ticked further into record territory on Thursday after the Federal...

The S&P 500 ticked further into record territory on Thursday after the Federal Reserve made a major overhaul to its strategy, one that could keep interest rates low for longer. The benchmark index rose 0.2%, to another all-time high, but it veered through ...

The S&P 500 ticked further into record territory on Thursday after the Federal Reserve made a major overhaul to its strategy, one that could keep interest rates low for longer. The benchmark index rose 0.2%, to another all-time high, but it veered through a jumbled day of trading to get there. Prices for stocks, bonds and gold all made several U-turns after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave a highly anticipated speech. In it, he essentially said the Fed may continue efforts to prop up the economy even if inflation rises above its target level of 2%, as long as it had been weak before then. The change in the Fed's strategy is a huge deal for markets. The central bank has been the superhero repeatedly rescuing them from crises through the years, by slashing short-term interest rates and buying all kinds of bonds. The momentous announcement was widely expected on Wall Street, if not on Thursday then later this year, but trading was nevertheless erratic following it. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 160.35 points, or 0.6%, to 28,492.27 after fading back from an earlier gain of 302 points. The Nasdaq composite, meanwhile, fell 39.72 points, or 0.3%, to 11,625.34 after paring an earlier loss of 1%. The benchmark S&P 500 gained 5.82 points to 3,484.55 to set a closing record for the fifth straight day. It's surged nearly 56% since late March after the immense support of the Fed helped halt its earlier free-fall and erase its pandemic losses. Low rates often act like steroids for stocks, allowing their prices to rise faster than corporate profits. “The era of easy money is here,” said Mike Loewengart, managing director of investment strategy at E-Trade Financial. Treasury yields fell immediately after Powell began talking, but then started bouncing up and down. The yield of the 10-year Treasury was at 0.74% after stocks stopped trading on Wall Street, up from 0.68% late Wednesday. The 30-year yield climbed to 1.50% from 1.41%. Shorter-term Treasury yields were more subdued, and the two-year yield held at 0.14%. The widening gap between short- and longer-term yields could be an indication of higher expectations for the economy or inflation among investors. Gold for delivery in December fell $19.90 to settle at $1,932.60 per ounce. Earlier, it had leaped to $1,968.80 after Powell began talking. Lower Treasury yields can drive demand for gold from investors seeking safety but not interested in the lower interest payments coming from bonds. Earlier in the morning, a report showed the pace of layoffssweeping the country remains incredibly high but may be slowing. A little more than 1 million U.S. workers applied for unemployment benefits last week, which was a dip from the slightly more than 1.1 million the prior week. “It puts a spotlight on the heavy lifting the economy is going to need to get people back in the jobs market,” said Marvin Loh, senior global macro strategist at State Street. He said investors are still banking on Congress delivering another round of aid for the economy, which could include benefits for unemployed workers. Much of Congress' last round of stimulus has expired, and investors say a renewal is critical, though partisan disagreements have prevented a deal. “It’s a necessary result that has to come out of Washington sooner rather than later,” Loh said. In another report, the government also said that the economy looks like it shrankat an annual rate of 31.7% in the spring quarter. That would be the sharpest quarterly drop on record, but it’s not as bad as the Commerce Department’s earlier estimate of 32.9%. Abbott Laboratories jumped 7.8% for one of the biggest gains in the S&P 500 after federal regulators gave emergency use authorization for its COVID-19 test, which can provide results in 15 minutes and will cost only $5. Stocks of companies that sorely need people feeling comfortable enough with the pandemic to get back to “normal” life were also strong. Live Nation Entertainment rose 8.8%, Norwegian Cruise Line was up 5.9% and United Airlines rallied 5.8%. Financial stocks had the biggest gain among the 11 sectors that make up the S&P 500, up 1.7%. A higher 10-year Treasury yield allows for higher rates on mortgages and other loans, which boosts profits for banks. JPMorgan Chase gained 3.3%, and Wells Fargo rose 2.3%. Counterbalancing those gains were losses for some big tech and internet companies, which gave back some of their slingshot, earlier gains. Apple slipped 1.2%. It's coming off four straight weeks where it rocketed up by 3% to 14.7%. In European stock markets, the German DAX lost 0.7%, and France's CAC 40 slipped 0.6%. The FTSE 100 in London was down 0.8%. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.4%, and South Korea's Kospi lost 1%. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong fell 0.8%, and stocks in Shanghai rose 0.6%. Benchmark U.S. crude oil fell 35 cents to settle at $43.04 per barrel. Brent crude, the international standard, lost 55 cents to $$45.09 per barrel.

Shorter-term Treasury yields were more subdued, and the two-year yield held at 0.14%. A higher 10-year Treasury yield allows for higher rates on mortgages and other loans, which boosts profits for banks. JPMorgan Chase gained 3.3%, and Wells Fargo rose 2.3%. Counterbalancing those gains were losses for some big tech and internet companies, which gave back some of their slingshot, earlier gains. Apple slipped 1.2%. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:600V-2721-JB20-G3GF-00000-00SpaceX, NASA Launch Scrubbed; Thousands Protest In Hong Kong Wednesday Over New Controversial National Security Law; U.S. No Longer Considers Hong Kong Autonomous From China; China's CDC Suggests Wuhan Virus Might Not Have Originated From Wuhan Wet Markets; Social Media Censorship; President Trump's National Security Chief Slashes Staff To Half Of Obama Levels; Trump Administration's Response To China; Interview With Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH); House Voting On FISA Reauthorization; Calls For Flynn- Kislyak Transcripts To Be Released2020-05-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:21ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTGordon Chang, K.T. McFarland, Jim JordanNEWSFinancial052701cb.229SpaceX, NASA Launch Scrubbed; Thousands Protest In Hong Kong Wednesday Over New Controversial National Security Law; U.S. No Longer Considers Hong Kong Autonomous From China; China's CDC Suggests Wuhan Virus Might Not Have Originated From Wuhan Wet Markets; Social Media Censorship; President Trump's National Security Chief Slashes Staff To Half Of Obama Levels; Trump Administration's Response To China; Interview With Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH); House Voting On FISA Reauthorization; Calls For Flynn- Kislyak Transcripts To Be ReleasedLou Dobbs, Susan Li, Sara Carter

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Good evening, everybody. What would have been an historic day for America put on hold for at least another few days, SpaceX just moments ago forced to scrub the launch of their Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral because of bad weather, including a nearby Tornado Watch.

The launch had been sent to end U.S. dependence on foreign nations principally Russia to send our astronauts into space, a 10-year dependency.

President Trump, the First Lady, Vice President Pence all in attendance at Cape Canaveral in hopes that the launch would take place, but stormy weather denying the crew enough time to load the liquid oxygen into the booster rocket. SpaceX will try again, Saturday afternoon, 3:22 Eastern Time.

Before leaving for Florida this morning, President Trump took direct aim at Big Tech in this country. President Trump is threatening to regulate, to even close down some social media platforms that he says are silencing conservative voices, and the evidence is on his side.

The President is angry and in my opinion, justifiably so. President Trump's warning comes only hours after Twitter slapped a fact check warning on two of his tweets about potential fraud involving early mail-in bail ballots.

The warning linking to fact checkers at leftwing fake news organizations -- if you can imagine this -- CNN, "The Washington Post," who say the President claims are false. So, we have fake news claims about the President's assertions on Twitter.

Twitter, however, chose not to disclose that it is an active and premier partner, excuse me, of Vote Early Day 2020. It's an organization and advocacy group pushing early voting. That's right, exactly what the President opposes, and vote by mail.

President Trump is now accusing Twitter of election interference and stifling free speech, his own -- imagine interfering with the President's free speech rights.

"Twitter has now shown," he tweets, " ... that everything we've been saying about them and their other compatriots is correct. Big action to follow."

Big action was taken today by the Trump administration against the Communist Chinese Party. Secretary of State Pompeo notifying Congress that Hong Kong is no longer autonomous and no longer warrants special treatment under U.S. law.

This, as riot police in Hong Kong took a zero tolerance approach to new demonstrations on the streets. Our own Susan Li with more now from New York -- Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Lou, running street battles return in Hong Kong as the Secretary of State Mike Pompeo says that Hong Kong is no longer independent.

We have thousands turning out in Hong Kong on Wednesday to protest a controversial National Security Bill. If passed, Beijing would be able to write security laws for Hong Kong without any input from the city, a move that many residents say would be the end of Hong Kong as we know it.

Over 300 arrested. Clashes taking place between protesters and police in several of the city's main districts.

Meantime, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has alerted Congress saying that, "After careful study of developments over the reporting period, I certified to Congress today that Hong Kong does not continue to warrant treatment under United States law in the same manner."

Now, remember that this was the underlying requirements in the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act that was passed by Congress and signed by President Trump last year.

If Beijing was deemed to be encroaching on Hong Kong's autonomy, the administration had a slate of tools to punish China, including sanctions, penalties and revoking visas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILBUR ROSS, U.S. COMMERCE SECRETARY: Well, there's a whole menu of potential things that he could do, and I'm sure they're working right now on exactly how to refine the thinking and come up with something that's an appropriate response.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: Now, speaking of response, China's propaganda arm, "The Global Times" tweeting about the U.S. response and the actions they may take, and they say, "If Washington rashly takes actions over Hong Kong, it could accelerate U.S. decoupling with the rest of the world, impair the vast interests of U.S. companies in the city and thus, generate negative impacts for President Trump's reelection efforts."

Though China hasn't passed the National Security Law just yet, it is expected to and then we'll see what the President decides to do -- Lou.

DOBBS: Susan, thank you very much. In short, there's not much it appears that the administration can do.

The Communist Chinese Party is spinning a new narrative about the origins now of the Wuhan virus. Chinese state media is saying the Hunan Seafood Market in Wuhan may not be the origin of the virus after all.

Scientists reportedly have discovered a new group of early virus patients in Shanghai that had no previous known connection to the market.

Other Chinese officials are also spinning up stories, maintaining that the virus did not originate in the Wuhan Institute of Virology, but they have yet to say exactly where it did come from or that it even originated in China.

The fact is, the Chinese lies continue, their disinformation propaganda campaign only intensifies.

A Canadian judge today saying the U.S. extradition case against Huawei's Chief Financial Officer may continue. The judge found the case against Meng Wanzhou meets the threshold of double criminality, meaning the charges against her are crimes in both the United States and Canada.

The Trump administration wants her to stand trial on charges linked to violations of U.S. sanctions against Iran.

Well, joining us tonight to take all of this up is Gordon Chang, columnist, author, Senior Fellow at the Gatestone Institute. Gordon, let's start with the listening to Wilbur Ross, the Secretary of Commerce talk rather gently around the answer, which is seemingly that the United States has very little it can do about Hong Kong, your thoughts?

GORDON CHANG, SENIOR FELLOW, GATESTONE INSTITUTE: We have a lot we can do about Hong Kong. And it's not just revoking the sanctions waivers and the tariff waivers.

I think that we should look at Hong Kong in the context of China, of course, and China's attack on the United States is broad based. It's across the board.

So, our response should be across the board. And of course, our response on Hong Kong will be part of that. So, we should be looking at trade prohibitions, investment prohibitions, all the rest of this.

DOBBS: Okay, all the rest of this. I don't still understand what action we can take that will change the outcome in Hong Kong, based on what you talked about as broad options. What are they? What specificity? What is the penalty that would be exacted on China?

CHANG: Well, you know, you're right, that we can't stop the passage of the Article 23 National Security Legislation, but you know, we have all sorts of tools to get U.S. companies out of China.

So for instance, the President can use his broad authorities under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977, and that means that he could force companies effectively off Chinese soil, and we could stop investment into China.

Also, he could get companies like Google to end their partnerships with basically the Chinese military on things like artificial intelligence.

DOBBS: The question becomes, 100,000 Americans killed by the virus that originated in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China and President Xi chose not to warn anyone in the world of the deadly contagion that they had unleashed.

Why would we be waiting to tell our companies to get out? Why would we be waiting to say this is an outrage against America and our national interest? Why would we not have already done so?

CHANG: Yes, we should have done that --

DOBBS: Because that is a greater crime, but proportionally, I'm saying to you, Gordon, that is a greater crime against America than what is being done in Hong Kong, as outrageous as it is.

CHANG: Well, you're absolutely right, Lou and we should be doing something immediately. And it was worse than Xi Jinping not saying anything about human to human transmissibility.

For a period of about five weeks, the Chinese leaders actually deliberately lied about the contagiousness of this disease and at the same time, they pressured countries to accept arrivals from China, not to impose those quarantines and restrictions.

And you put those two actions together, it shows that --

DOBBS: Well, the finer -- yes.

CHANG: You put those two together --

DOBBS: To put a finer point on it, Gordon, what we're really saying is that the Chinese government sent their nationals who were sick and had been likely contaminated on international flights as they were shutting down domestic flights within China. The evidence speaks for itself.

The decisions speak for themselves. It was an outrage against the world.

CHANG: And it was more than just the mass worldwide killing that President Trump talked about. It actually is akin to murder. So, we have 100,000 Americans dead, and we cannot forget this.

And by the way, Lou, we've got to deter Chinese leaders from doing this again, because this is not the last pathogen that's going to be generated on Chinese soil.

Chinese virologists, actually, this last week said, there's going to be more of these outbreaks, which means we've got to make sure that we protect ourselves and because Chinese communism is unreformable, the only way to protect ourselves is to reduce our exposure to China, which means no trade, no investment, no tech partnerships -- no nothing.

DOBBS: And do you believe that the Trump administration is responding proportionally and correctly in this crisis?

CHANG: I think the Trump administration is moving as fast as popular opinion will let it. I believe though that we should be moving faster.

DOBBS: Oh, those are damning words, Gordon. Those are damning words. This President is not a politician. He is arguably the greatest President in our history and you're telling me that he is waiting on popular opinion to make decisions about national security and the national interest?

CHANG: He is moving faster than any President before him and that's important, because right now --

DOBBS: Well, no President before him, in all fairness, had 100,000 Americans dead as a result of the action of the Communist Chinese government, did they?

CHANG: No, they didn't, and we, Americans have yet to come to the conclusion that this was deliberate murder. But President Trump has been leading public opinion in that direction.

DOBBS: But what else could you call it? What else could you call it?

CHANG: I believe it's mass murder, because this was deliberate. When you look at the actions of the Chinese government, we of course, don't know what -- we don't know what was in Xi Jinping's mind. But if, after having seen what --

DOBBS: But who cares what was in his mind? Who cares what was in his mind? He made a conscious decision not to warn the world of the deadly contagion that the Chinese had unleashed. What more do you need to know?

CHANG: He actually lied. He lied. It was more than just not telling the world.

DOBBS: He did.

CHANG: He lied, and what I was saying Lou is that --

DOBBS: Any one of them is enough.

CHANG: Absolutely. This was murder.

DOBBS: Gordon Chang, good to have you with us. Good to see you.

On Wall Street today, stocks rallied. The Dow up 553 points despite rising tensions between the United States and the Communist Chinese. The S&P up 44 points. The NASDAQ gained 72. Volume on the big board, 6.4 billion shares.

And crude oil down more than four percent to $32.82 a barrel.

A reminder to listen to my reports three times a day, coast-to-coast on the Salem Radio Network.

Up next, former Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein is about to become a very important witness in Obamagate. We take that up and more with Congressman Jim Jordan. He joins us here next as we take up Twitter's established rampant anti-Trump bias and the Silicon Valley billionaires who want nothing more than to just help out poor Sleepy Joe Biden.

Sara Carter with those stories and more right after these quick messages, please stay with us.

DOBBS: Breaking news now, a number of Republican senators, RINOs all, writing to President Trump today, urging him not to restrict temporary work visas, which they say will actually help the economic recovery.

That is to say they are RINOs. They know nothing about economics and they're willing to lie to the President of the United States. Here they are. Lindsey Graham, John Cornyn, Mike Crapo, James Risch, Mike Rounds, Todd Young, Lisa Murkowski, Dan Sullivan and James Lankford.

These senators know nothing about economics. They know nothing about the American people when almost 40 million American workers are unemployed within the last nine weeks alone. And these conscience-less senators have the temerity to write to the President asking them to bring in more foreign workers. The unemployment rate at 15 percent.

And I want to challenge any of these senators to come out of their shadows, step into our cameras and debate me on this issue. If you have any integrity, any guts, whatsoever, and I doubt very seriously that a single one of them will do so.

They're appalling, each and every one of them.

Well, breaking news tonight, tech billionaires, well, they're spending big money because that's their way, after all, they are billionaires. They want to help Joe Biden catch up with President Trump on his digital campaigning.

They include these Big Tech folks, LinkedIn founder Reed Hoffman, Facebook's co-founder Dustin Moskovitz, as well as Steve Jobs widow, Lauren Powell Jobs and former Google CEO, of course, Eric Schmidt, all wanting to help out Sleepy Joe.

Well, the Twitter official responsible for the platform's fact checking policy has a history of being anti-Trump, making anti-Trump comments, anti- conservative comments. His name is Yoel Roth.

He has tweeted in the past that there are, quote, "actual Nazis in the White House" end quote.

And quote, "I'm just saying, we fly over those states that voted for a racist tangerine for a reason." End quote. And this is just incredible.

Joining us tonight to take this up Sara Carter. She is investigative reporter, Fox Business contributor, Sara, great to have you with us.

SARA CARTER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Good to be with you, Lou. Thank you.

DOBBS: Whatever makes you tick, it's not -- it is obviously not decency, and it sure is hell not neutrality or objectivity.

CARTER: No, absolutely not. You're 100 percent right. You could just see by Yoel Roth's, his own tweets that were never fact checked, by the way by Twitter, complete lies absolutely politically biased.

He obviously hates Trump. He hates the Trump administration. And we see this consistently that there's this bias on Twitter, Lou and on Facebook, and other media platforms like Google.

I've talked to insiders before that have said, we know it is happening. You know, we've reported on it. There have been whistleblowers, and unfortunately what we're seeing is these high tech companies with a lot of power, basically putting themselves into the middle of the election.

Now, it was Twitter and Facebook that actually said in the beginning, look, we need to do something. We need to stop fake news because of what happened with Russia.

But actually, they've invested more in getting involved in the election than we've seen from other countries.

For example, they did this to President Trump, right? As far as like fact checking his tweets about mail-in ballots, but they've never done that to China. They have never done this to Iran. They have never done this to Turkey.

When they put out these false tweets, basically targeting individuals and people, we saw that in Iran with Israel saying that Israel should be taken off the map, but Twitter never fact check them.

So, there's a serious problem here, and I think President Trump is right. We need to look into this. We need a White House panel to investigate this. And we need to hold Twitter and Facebook accountable because they're actually preferencing the Democrats in the upcoming election.

DOBBS: This is an outrage, an absolute outrage. The President has every right to be furious, and by the way, I'm not a fan of further investigation. This is on its face what it is.

I thought Donald Trump, Jr. got it exactly right with a tweet. This is what he tweeted, "So is @Twitter going to start censoring and fact checking all the numerous blue checkmark, journalists and leftwing activists who falsely claim that the Trump Campaign colluded with the Russian government, and that @RealDonaldTrump is a puppet of Putin for the past four years?" Sara, your thoughts?

CARTER: Right. Well, Donald Trump, Jr. is 100 percent right. How many stories have been out there that basically called out -- this is supposedly from "The New York Times," "Washington Post," supposedly trustworthy news sources, right?

For the last three and a half years to four years, they have been pushing stories that President Trump is The Manchurian Candidate, that he is actually connected to Russia.

Faults on their face. Faults on their face. They have never once retracted these stories, and Twitter has never corrected them.

So Donald Trump, Jr. is the absolutely right when he is doing this.

DOBBS: But you know what I hope we don't fall into, and it's one of the few times I would argue with you about anything but this idea of investigations, we know what they are, we know what they're doing. They have a public record. And they should be brought to heel.

They're not news organizations. They are, at best carriers. And it really must -- it really has to stop now. This is not something that can wait until after the election or -- it has just got to be dealt with.

And frankly, Dempsey and his crew are a bunch of leftwing, fill in the blanks, if you will. Sara, I appreciate you being here. We've got a lot of work to do in this country to straighten out Big Tech, but it is -- there's going to have to reckoning.

I thought Brad Parscale, the President's campaign manager was going to do that a couple of years ago. I guess he didn't get around to it.

Thanks so much, Sara Carter, as always, we appreciate it.

We'd like to hear your thoughts on all of this. Share your comments and follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs. Like me on Facebook. Follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

And Dr. Michael Pillsbury; investigative journalist, John Solomon among our guests here tomorrow evening. Please be with us for that.

And coming up here next tonight, President Trump says it's time to bring our soldiers in Afghanistan home. We take that up and much more, former Trump Deputy National Security Adviser Katie McFarland with us. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: White House National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien dramatically cutting the size of the National Security Council staff.

O'Brien doing what he said he would do when he took the job. He expects to have only 105 staffers by the end of summer. That's more than half of the 240 staffers who worked at the N.S.C. under President Obama.

Women will also make up half of N.S.C.'s senior leadership for the first time in history.

U.S. troops in Afghanistan could be back home before the upcoming November election. Top military officials telling us that the President has given them orders to create numerous plans to withdraw all of our troops in Afghanistan.

There are currently fewer than 12,000 troops there, and the President wants them all home.

Joining us tonight is K.T. McFarland, former Deputy National Security Adviser to President Trump, author of the book "Revolution: Trump, Washington, and We, the People." We recommend the book to you highly and commend K.T. as always for the book and delighted to have you with us, K.T.

First, Robert O'Brien cutting half the staff. He said he was going to streamline it and he has done precisely that. What is the effect of doing so?

K.T. MCFARLAND, FORMER DEPUTY NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER TO PRESIDENT TRUMP: Well, I talked to him today, actually, Lou about this and other topics, and he's very happy to have finally been able to do it.

He is also, as you point out, he is very happy that the women on the staff make up 50 percent of the senior positions, and they're there on merit, not on tokenism.

And I think that what it'll allow him to do is really respond and give President Trump the kind of National Security Council he needs. You know, for the first year or two of the administration, I'm sorry to say that the National Security Council was really working at odds or many of the people were working at odds with the President's agenda.

I mean, they thought that President Trump should work for them, and that they would set the agenda not the other way around.

And with Robert O'Brien, he has now --

DOBBS: Or work for President Obama.

MCFARLAND: Oh, sorry. They worked for President Obama, right, they were the Obama holdovers. They certainly didn't think that they should be having to work for President Trump.

Well, anyway, now President Trump has the National Security Council he needs, which is very good, because, you know, every president should have a National Security Council that suits its needs.

President Trump, unlike a lot of other Presidents, he makes the decisions himself. He doesn't just pick option one, two or three that are sort of spoon fed to him by the bureaucracy.

So, I think now, he's got the right people in the right places. And I do think that American foreign policy and National Security policy will really quickly be able to implement President Trump's objectives.

DOBBS: Give us your sense, though, what is being projected from the White House right now? Because there is an incredible, I think, an unprecedented number of crises that are contemporaneous, whether it is the Wuhan virus, whether it is an intense disinformation and propaganda campaign by one of the principal powers of the world, and that is China.

At the same time, taking over Hong Kong because that's what it is. We all know it and we all might as well use plain English when we say it.

And there is here, a President that needs as much counsel, as much help and support as he possibly can get.

We are not necessarily hearing that there is some sort of perfect equivalency between taking the rights away from the citizens of Hong Kong and the loss of 100,000 American lives.

But we're not hearing that there will be a reckoning and an accounting and retribution for killing Americans consciously and doing so with absolute impunity.

MCFARLAND: You know, one of the things I did talk to Robert O'Brien about today was China, and he said that watch in the coming days -- days -- and coming weeks, that they're starting to roll out a policy, a comprehensive policy of dealing with China.

Just today, Secretary of State Pompeo designated Hong Kong is no longer an independent country. So, it has economic effects and trading effects and financial investment effects on Hong Kong, which will hurt China.

The second thing is, though, I think President Trump unlike the past two Presidents, unlike the entire Washington establishment, who for 20 years, put China's interests first and America's interest second, and in promoting China's interest it was often at the expense of America's interest.

I think President Trump has really changed the conversation in the country, and he has changed the direction of American foreign policy.

He is standing tough and standing tall against China. He did from the beginning, and I think that the coronavirus has really -- it really is a wake-up call. I mean, not to President Trump, he already knew there was a problem. It was a wake-up call to the rest of the world.

DOBBS: You call it coronavirus. The President called it the China virus. He called it the Wuhan virus, and even the Chinese called it the Wuhan virus, but we just heard you say coronavirus and we haven't heard the President use the expression, China virus when whether it's Ebola, whether it's -- you name the virus, they're all -- nearly all named for places.

But suddenly it's politically incorrect to call this the Wuhan virus. I am tired. I'm tired of thought control in the form of correct language.

This is what it is and Americans have been plainspoken, no one more plain spoken than this President. It disturbs me to see any retreat from that vivid and straightforward expression on the part of the White House.

MCFARLAND: Well, you know, I think that you've got a point in the sense of what are we calling it, because words do matter.

But when I look at what President Trump is doing, I think that the deeds that he's doing are really significant.

You know, in Washington, everybody says everything. They don't really mean anything, and they really never follow through with what they're talking about and promising.

And I think that President Trump has really been very different in that regard.

DOBBS: Well, let's conclude with a question and an answer.

MCFARLAND: Yes.

DOBBS: Is Xi Jinping and the Communist Chinese government responsible for the deaths of 100,000 Americans?

MCFARLAND: Not only 100,000 Americans, but people all around the world. The Chinese shoes, the virus, whatever you want to call it.

DOBBS: I am going to be parochial, if I may, K.T.

MCFARLAND: Sure.

DOBBS: It is in your judgment, murder, I think so, too. I think it's odd that we --

MCFARLAND: I think it was a bio weapon that killed American people, and they are trying to kill the American economy.

DOBBS: You know, K.T., that's why you're welcome on this broadcast every day. We appreciate your straightforward insight and by the way, succinct answers as well from time to time.

K.T., thank you so much. We appreciate it.

MCFARLAND: Thanks very much, Lou.

DOBBS: Up next, what -- you bet. Good to see you. What will we learn from Rod Rosenstein about Obamagate? Congressman Jim Jordan joins us this evening on that and much more. Please stay with us.

DOBBS: Breaking news now. Lindsey Graham finally taking long promised action to investigate the radical Dems efforts to overthrow President Trump.

The Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman announcing that former Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein will testify next Wednesday, that's June 3rd.

The hearing will take place one day before the committee votes on subpoena authorizations to compel more witnesses.

And here we go.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi moving ahead with a House vote tonight to reauthorize three expired surveillance programs. But it may have some trouble getting the 218 votes needed now to clear the chamber. Partly because President Trump urged Republicans to oppose the measure tweeting this, "I hope all Republican House members vote no on FISA until such time as our country is able to determine how and why the greatest political, criminal and subversive scandal in USA history took place."

The Justice Department also weighing in today, saying President Trump should veto the bill if it passes, but this is an interesting piece of maneuvering on the part of the Justice Department.

Congressman Jim Jordan says he hopes to soon see the transcripts of Michael Flynn's phone calls with former Russian diplomat, Sergey Kislyak, the Russian Ambassador to the United States.

Those transcripts were declassified by the outgoing Director of National Intelligence, Richard Grenell. It's now up to the new Intel Chief, John Ratcliffe, to release those documents.

What will happen? Well, let's get the best view on that possible. Congressman Jim Jordan joining us tonight. Congressman Jordan is a Ranking Member of the House Oversight Committee, also a member of the House Judiciary Committee.

Congressman, great to have you with us. Let's start with the House vote tonight on this Bill. This is quite a spectacle. The President not threatening to veto it, but calling on House Republicans not to support it.

But he didn't make a position known when you originally voted on the Bill. Give us some insight here.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Well, here's what's happening. Good to be with you, Lou. Here's what happened in the last two months.

So back when this first passed in March, since that time, think about what we've learned. We've learned 39 people unmasked Michael Flynn's name. We learned how they set up Michael Flynn.

We've got these transcripts that Mr. Grenell got released that show that when the whole Trump-Russia investigation started, there was no basis for doing the investigation, something you and I thought all along and knew all along, but now it's true.

Clapper knew and Brennan knew there was nothing there. Comey knew there was nothing there. So, all of that has transpired since then, and more importantly, we have the memorandum from Inspector General Horowitz, who is looking broadly at the FISA now.

First, he looked at what they did to Carter Page and the Trump campaign. Now, he is looking broadly at the FISA, and he put out a memorandum back on March 30th, which said, the 29 cases he has looked at, every single one -- every single one had major problems.

Four others, Lou, didn't even have what's called the Woods File, which is the file you have where you keep the main evidence, the supporting evidence, documentation for what you then take to the FISA Court.

So 29 American citizens who were spied on, every single one of those had major problems. So, that's all transpired since that first vote, and the President is simply saying, look, until we get this all figured out, we ain't reauthorizing anything. We're not doing it.

So God bless the President. This is a good product we've got working, but it can get better, and that's what the President wants to see happen.

DOBBS: I will second your God bless for this President because of what he has endured, all that he has done for the country, and then have to ask the Republicans to stop more of the madness.

I also don't quite understand the madness from the Justice Department, and perhaps you can give us some insight into that talking about given the cumulative negative effect of the legislative changes on the department's ability to spy, they want the President to veto it for an entirely different reason.

JORDAN: For a different reason.

DOBBS: What in the hell is going on at the Justice Department, Congressman?

JORDAN: Well, look at what the President tweeted out, though, just a few hours ago. He said, there should be no warrantless searches on American citizens and amen to that as well.

So, this President understands it and he has lived through it. Mr. Horowitz has given us the evidence and he had done the investigations that show just how bad it is.

So like the President said, let's get to the bottom of all of this before we reauthorize the program that was abused by Jim Comey's F.B.I. and the Intelligence Community in the Obama administration.

Hey, Lou, think about this. Six people in the Treasury Department were unmasking Michael Flynn's name, in the Treasury Department, six different people. Holy cow. What was going on in those last several weeks of the Obama administration?

We're now beginning to understand how determined they were to go after this President, how determined they were to cover up their scheme that they had back in their administration. And Jim Comey was the guy who was going to protect them because he was going into the next administration.

And then when he gets fired, Bob Mueller is going to protect them. But finally, we are getting the answers, getting to the details, getting to the facts, and that's why we're holding this up until we get a better product for the President to sign.

DOBBS: A better product. I like the idea that you don't sign a damn thing. There's no excuse to be spying on Americans for any reason and that crap has got to end. That's just one opinion.

JORDAN: Right opinion.

DOBBS: We're going to seek your opinion on what we're going to learn from - - thank you, sir. We're going to get your opinion about Lindsey Graham, sort of a, I guess he's an investigator now and he is going to have Rod Rosenstein before him.

We're going to get Congressman Jim Jordan's view of what we can expect. Stay with us. We'll be back with Congressman Jim Jordan, great American.

DOBBS: Former acting D.N.I. Ric Grenell setting former U.N. Ambassador Samantha Power straight in one of his last acts, power claiming today Senator Marco Rubio has sounded the alarm about peddling Trump conspiracy theories, and how that does Russia's disinformation work somehow.

Grenell quickly replied, "After spending years peddling a Russian collusion hoax, but under oath admitting you saw nothing, forgive us if we ignore your new so-called warnings."

We're joined once again by Congressman Jim Jordan. What do you think of the job Ric Grenell did as D.N.I.?

JORDAN: Amazing. I mean, three months -- compare three months of Ric Grinell with three years of Chris Wray. I mean, Ric Grenell got things done and he is right about Samantha Power and her so-called, you know, warning.

I mean, for goodness sake, they took a dossier to a secret court, a dossier they knew was false. They knew it was unverified. They knew it was paid for by the Clinton campaign. They knew it was Russian disinformation and they used that to get a warrant to go spy on President Trump's campaign.

And now they're lecturing us?

And then Jim Comey goes up to Trump Tower in early January in 2017 and tells the President about that dossier that he already knew was false and that he knew was paid for by the Clintons, that he knew was Russian disinformation, talks to the President about it so they can leak it and the press will report the fact that he's talked to the President about it.

And they want to lecture us so.

You can't make this stuff up and it is just ridiculous what we hear from some of these Democrats.

DOBBS: Ridiculous. Tragic. And how do the Democrats find so many creepy people to aggregate in one place in the swamp? It is just -- it is appalling. It's downright scary.

JORDAN: Thirty nine of them unmasking Michael Flynn, 39 of them unmasking Michael Flynn's name, too.

DOBBS: They apparently meant to get it done.

JORDAN: Yes.

DOBBS: Rod Rosenstein, first witness before the long awaited Senator Graham committee, the Judiciary Committee. What do you expect to happen? What do you hope to see?

JORDAN: Well, no, I think it's great that Lindsey is bringing him in. You know, remember Rod Rosenstein was the guy who was there during that critical time in May of 2017.

Jim Comey gets fired on May 9th. Bob Mueller gets named special counsel on May 17th. Those eight days are critical because we deposed Jim Baker, the former Chief Counsel at the F.B.I., and Jim Baker told us in that eight-day time frame, the people at the F.B.I. were looking to -- Rod Rosenstein was looking to wear a wire to record the President of the United States.

Rod Rosenstein was looking to invoke the 25th Amendment and remove the President from office. Rod Rosenstein was talking about -- and Andy McCabe and these guys were talking about an obstruction of justice investigation into the President.

And what they ultimately settled on doing, their course of action was to get Bob Mueller named as Special Counsel and Jim Comey leaked his memos to create the momentum to get Bob Mueller as the Special Counsel.

And two years later and $30 million and all the subpoenas, everything else they did, they came back with what they already knew. There was nothing there.

So yes, I think Rod Rosenstein is a good person to bring in right away, and let's find out what he knows about wearing a wire what he was doing about the 25th Amendment and these other issues that that came up in that critical, critical timeframe in May of '17.

DOBBS: Do you get the sense of Lindsey Graham this time means to actually find something out, because he went more than a year after promising to investigate the investigators? Of course, he has immediately ruled out any possible prosecution of President Obama or former Vice President Biden, strange ways to go, but then it is the Senate Judiciary Committee after all, your thoughts?

JORDAN: No, I do. You know, they're going to subpoena a number of people. I think that is real important. I keep coming back to this fact.

The insurance policy started off as the investigation itself. Once the President won the election, I think the insurance policy turned into, well, we've got to make sure Michael Flynn doesn't stay as his National Security Adviser in The Trump administration because he knows about Intelligence.

He might find out what we did. So, they get rid of Michael Flynn and Jim Comey is the guy who is going to travel into the next administration and protect him.

When he gets fired, it becomes -- Bob Mueller becomes the Special Counsel that becomes the insurance policy.

We've got to -- there's a lot of people I think we need to talk to. Lindsey is going to subpoena them all. And I think, make sure they come in and hopefully get to the bottom of all this.

DOBBS: Congressman, John Ratcliffe, you've worked with him, served with him in the Congress as the D.N.I., do you think that he will release those transcripts for General Flynn that were declassified by Ric Grenell?

JORDAN: Yes, I think you will. I think John Ratcliffe is a good man. I think he's going to do the great work like Ric Grenell started there. I look forward to working with him.

I want that transcript between Mr. Flynn and Mr. Kislyak. I want the original 302. Remember, when Peter Strzok and Pientka go in and try to set up Mike Flynn on Comey's orders. There's the initial 302, the notes taken to that interview, and then it was changed by Peter Strzok.

So, I want to see the Kislyak-Flynn conversation. I want to see the original 302 and then I want to see the one that was doctored, the one that was amended and written by Peter Strzok. I want to see all three of those documents.

We have asked to get access to that as well from Christopher Wray, those 302s. We've also asked to make sure we get a chance to interview Mr. Pientka at some time. So hopefully we'll be able to get all of that information.

DOBBS: Congressman, great to have you with us. Very quickly, we're out of time, but does the vote fail or pass on the FISA reauthorization today?

JORDAN: I think it's going to lose because you're going to see the vast majority of us Republicans oppose it. And I think it's going to be tough to see if it passes.

The other interesting thing is I think there are 70 something Democrats, Lou, who aren't even showing up. They're mailing in the vote. They're phoning it in to a colleague via proxy and some colleagues are going to vote for them.

So it will be interesting to see how it all shakes out here in a few hours.

DOBBS: Better watch that mail-in vote there in the House.

JORDAN: No kidding. No kidding.

DOBBS: A lot of fraud associated with that.

JORDAN: Exactly right.

DOBBS: Congressman Jim Jordan. Thanks for being with us. We'll be right back with much more. Stay with us.

DOBBS: President Trump just moments ago tweeted he'll be in Florida for SpaceX's second effort to launch American astronauts into space, 3:22 Eastern, Saturday.

That's it for us tonight. Michael Pillsbury and investigative journalist, John Solomon among our guests here tomorrow. Please join us for that. Good night from Sussex.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y7R-8RC1-JBJN-M062-00000-00Spain approves Google levy and financial transaction tax2020-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:20ZLexisNexisSpain approves Google levy and financial transaction tax


The Spanish Council of Ministers on Tuesday approved draft laws for the creation of new taxes on certain digital services and financial transactions. In addition, he signed a Royal Decree-Law containing the repeal of Article 52(d) of the Workers' Statute that allows employers to dismiss a worker for the objective dismissal of a worker for accumulating justified medical leave.


The king today presided in the Palace of Zarzuela his first Council of Ministers of the coalition government chaired by Pedro Sánchez. It is the second time that King Felipe VI has met with the ministerial cabinet since he acceded to the throne, after he did so with the Executive led by Mariano Rajoy in July 2018, also in Zarzuela.
The Executive meeting with the king has been a previous advisory appointment to be held by the cabinet in Moncloa in which the Government has given the green light to the decisions provided for in this week's agenda: new taxes on financial transactions and certain digital services, known as Tobin and Google rates, and has eliminated the possibility of firing for chaining sick leave.
Digital tax and financial transactions
The Government passed the preliminary draft laws for the creation of new taxes on certain digital services, also known as the Google levy,and to financial transactions, also called the Tobin rate,whose bills declined in the last legislature in the face of electoral advances. The governance agreement between PSOE and Unidas Podemos included the approval of both taxes. The Government expects a collection of EUR 1,818 million at both fees, below the estimated 2.050 million last year as a result of the economic slowdown.
The new Tax on Certain Digital Services, known as'Google fee',will predictably be taxed by companies with total annual revenues of at least 750 million euros and with revenues in Spain in excess of 3 million euros.
The novelty that the Government has included is that, although the settlement of this tax will be quarterly, "this year exceptionally will not be done until December 20 and this will give us a margin for negotiations at the international level and allow companies to adapt better," said the Minister of Finance, María Jesús Montero.
In particular, in line with the proposal made by the European Commission at the time,it will tax 3% of online advertising services, online intermediation services and the sale of data generated from information provided by the user during its activity or the sale of metadata. The Government expects to raise EUR 1.2 billion with this tax, the liquidation of which will be quarterly.
In the Government's 2019 draft public accounts, the revenue estimate was EUR 1.2 billion with this tax, while now the Executive hopes to raise 968 million.
The Government defends the creation of this levy because there are incomes obtained in Spain by large international companies from certain digital activities that escape the current fiscal framework, so they are making competitionunfair especially to small trade.
The sale of goods or services between users under an online intermediation service is excluded from the tax; and sales of goods or services contracted online through the provider's website of those goods or services in which the supplier does not act as an intermediary. In addition, certain financial services are excluded from the fee.
In addition, digital benefits that are made between entities that are part of a group with a direct or indirect share of 100% will also be excluded from the tax.
The government's tax is similar to that passed by France last year and whose entry into force has sparked after reaching an agreement with the United States, which had announced the imposition of tariffs on French products on the grounds that this digital tax primarily penalized America's big tech giants, such as Amazon,Google, or Facebook.
For now, the Gallic country defers the tax until one is paced internationally in the orbit of the OECD and the Trump Administration also cripples tariffs on French products. What is to be seen is how the United States will take this new tax in Spain and whether it will apply new tariffs on Spanish products, as it already did in the French case.
Along with this tax, the Council of Ministers on Tuesday approved the bill creating the Financial Transactiontax, known as the 'Tobin rate', which will tax with 0.2% the transactions of purchase of Spanish shares executed by traders of the financial sector.
Only 0.2% of the acquisition of shares issued in Spain of listed companies with a market capitalization of more than 1 billion euros will be subject to taxation. The purchase of shares of SMEs and unlisted companies will not be taxed. The taxable person is the financial intermediary who transmits or executes the purchase order, and must file an annual tax return.
Debt, both public and private, and derivatives are outside the scope of the 'Tobin rate'. In particular, acquisitions that will be exempt from this levy include the operations of the primary market (ipode of a company), those necessary for the operation of market infrastructures, those of corporate restructuring , those between companies in the same group and temporary assignments.
The Government estimates that it will deposit some 850 million for this new tax figure, which will be used to finance pensions and the social security protection system.
Repeal of casualty layoffs
The repeal of this article was announced by the Minister of Labour and Social Economy, Yolanda Díaz, shortly after arriving in office and has been approved today after going through the appropriate administrative procedures.
This article, which was amended with the 2012 labour reform, states that an employment contract may be terminated due to unassisted work failures, which are still justified but intermittent, reaching 20% of working hours in two consecutive months, provided that the total number of attendance failures in the previous twelve months reaches 5% of working hours or 25% in four discontinued months within a 12-month period.
The abolition of 52.d comes after the Constitutional Court, in a judgment known at the end of October, endorsed the termination of the employment contract on objective grounds if there are justified but intermittent lack of assistance.
What is approved today is the repeal of the article, not its modification or its replacementby other text. In this way, dismissal for accumulation of justified medical casualties will no longer be an objective cause for the dismissal of a worker.
This does not mean that an employer cannot fire someone from his staff for lack of assistance or untimely, as he could argue this reason for carrying out what is known as disciplinary dismissal.
The Minister of Labour has repeatedly stressed that the repeal of Article 52.d will be "great news" to stop living degrading situations in Spain and thus prevent a worker from losing his job while in a situation vulnerable.
Union satisfaction and some criticism from the employer
The repeal of this article has not been part of the social dialogue, although the minister did inform trade unions and employers of its approval. While CCOO and UGT have welcomed the adoption of this Royal Decree-Law, in some sectors of the CEOE it is not viewed with good eyes.
The president of the trustee, Antonio Garamendi, has not been in front of the repeal of this article, although he has suggested that the first seven days of leave, especially in the case of SMEs, "pay them for the Administration". In his opinion, we should go much deeper into the issue of absenteeism "because professional absenteeism is a reality in Spain".
For his part, the president of the Catalan employer Foment del Treball and vice-president of the CEOE, Josep Sánchez Llibre, has expressed his opposition to the repeal of this article.
The Labour Minister believes that the business rejection of this measure is a minority and has made it clear that the Government has an obligation to legislate "to correct what is already the source of European law".
More legal certainty in electronic services
The Council of Ministers also approved, on a proposal from the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Digital Transformation, a draft law adapting national law to Community regulation to strengthen security in the use of certain trusted electronic services.
These services include the signature and electronic seal of natural and legal persons or the electronic time stamp, which are commonly used in the telematic relations of citizens, companies and public administrations.
The regulation provides for certain technical and internal organisational aspects to be established by the national legislature, regulating, inter alia, the verification of the identity and attributes of applicants for a qualified certificate.
It also regulates the liability and risk forecasting regime of service providers, the maximum period of validity of the certificates, the time of retention of the service data, the legal effects of the documents where a qualified trusted service and a new sanctioning regime have been used, extended to all services that are trusted and appropriate to the European regulation.
The project also appoints the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Digital Transformation as the body responsible for overseeing trusted service providers and building the list of trusted services.
Spain is the country of the European Union with the largest number of qualified service providers, including the National Mint and Stamp Factory or the Directorate-General of the Police.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5FJH-YHF1-DYWT-T45X-00000-00Spain finance: Simple but uncertain2014-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:20ZLexisNexisPg. 13Spain finance: Simple but uncertainPart 13 of 25Virtual banking: Simple but uncertain

A Spanish bank's purchase of an American start-up raises big questions

FRANCISCO GONZALEZ, the chairman of Spain's second-largest bank, BBVA, loves to talk about technology. Even as the financial crisis raged, the former computer programmer has talked up the importance of upgrading the bank's systems. On February 20th, BBVA bought Simple, an American online-banking platform, for $117m, in a deal that hints at the potential for innovators to shake up retail banking.

BBVA, with EUR607 billion in assets and 50m customers, believes that traditional banks will soon lose their monopoly on banking. In an opinion piece in the Financial Times last year, Mr Gonzalez warned that banks faced certain death unless they took on the likes of Amazon or Google. New entrants will not have the legacy costs of banks and can tempt clients with convenient mobile apps. He predicts mobile services could even triple the number of bank customers worldwide in the next decade.

Internet banking has had false starts before and thus far big tech companies have not really ventured into the low-margin, highly regulated and capital-intensive world of retail banking. True, non-banks have had some success in places like Kenya, which lacks an adequate banking network. And niche players like PayPal are thriving in payments. But their impact has been limited. "I am dying to fund a disruptive bank," Marc Andreessen, a venture capitalist, recently tweeted.

Banks have several lines of defence, says Jason Napier, an analyst at Deutsche Bank. They have millions of customers who tend to stay put. What is more, barriers to replicating technology are relatively low: cool new apps developed in Silicon Valley can be quickly copied by banks.

Still, he says a revolution is afoot, if not perceptible. As consumers do more banking on their mobile phones, visits to branches are falling. Simple says its clients login 2.4 times a day, on average. That compares with the mere handful of interactions most customers have with bank branches in a year. Its app allows users to work out how much it is "safe to spend" instead of simply providing a current balance. And it allows them to extract complex information easily by asking, for instance, how much they had spent on coffee and taxis in New York over the past month. Simple's base of young customers has grown by 330% in a year to 100,000.

If technology barriers are low, why didn't BBVA simply develop its own app? Time may be one factor. Another may be culture. Carlos Torres, head of BBVA's strategy and corporate development, says it is hard for a large organisation to replicate the entrepreneurial talent of an upstart. The Simple deal also suggests new entrants might still need banks. Simple itself is not regulated as a bank. Instead it places customers' funds with the Bancorp, which provides banking services to other firms. BBVA plans to move these funds to Compass, its American subsidiary.

The challenge for BBVA is to make Simple profitable. It plans to roll out new products, such as mortgages, in addition to the checking account that Simple currently offers. BBVA's focus will be on America where its retail business is still sub-scale. In time it hopes to introduce Simple in BBVA's core markets, including Spain and Mexico. It is not clear whether BBVA will eventually adopt Simple's technology for its own clients, or keep it independent.

For other lenders, upgrading creaky infrastructure to allow zippy functions along the lines of Simple's may be costly, but savings will come from fewer branches. And they still have the heft to buy pesky upstarts that threaten to disrupt them.
